data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Bubblepoint, you’re conflating two different things deliberately or otherwise…. RNSs are not meant to read like investor presentations or broker models…. they are regulatory disclosures, and by design they don’t include forward guidance, speculative cash forecasts, or granular commercial negotiations…. That doesn’t make the facts that are disclosed meaningless…. £30m total debt is a fact…. the workover being funded from cash is a fact…. materially higher production post-workover is a fact…. lower opex versus last year is a fact…. and legacy hedges rolling off into a stronger pricing environment is also a fact…. You keep saying “no facts” while ignoring the ones that don’t fit your narrative…. then you fall back on history as if companies are not allowed to change trajectory after restructuring…. that’s analysis anchored in the past, not what’s happening now…. No one here is claiming RNSs tell the entire story…. but they don’t need to…. what matters is direction of travel, and that direction has clearly improved compared with where Angus was heading into default last year…. Cash generation improving, costs down, production up, and debt being restructured at lower rates is not a “wet dream”…. it’s a stabilisation phase…. and stabilisation is exactly what precedes rerating in situations like this…. You’re free to remain sceptical…. but dismissing every positive development as fiction doesn’t make it so…. it just means you’re choosing not to engage with the facts that are already on the table….

Calling the recent production uplift a “rabbit out of the hat” ignores the fact that Saltfleetby has always been capable of higher rates once constraints were addressed…. the latest RNS confirms a material improvement following the workover, not some cosmetic bounce…. On the share count point, yes there are a lot of shares in issue…. that’s already well known and fully reflected in the price…. what changes outcomes isn’t the historical capital structure, it’s cash generation and balance sheet repair, and that’s exactly where things are improving…. As for the “new well” scepticism, nobody is pretending it’s risk-free or imminent tomorrow…. the point is that higher current production and stronger margins give Angus options they simply didn’t have before…. optionality matters when a company is coming out of a stressed period…. You also keep anchoring to falling gas prices as if that’s a certainty…. prices fluctuate, but Angus is producing now, into a materially better pricing environment than most of 2024, with legacy hedges rolling off and a much leaner cost base…. that combination is what improves margins, not a single headline price…. No one sensible is saying this is a guaranteed straight line to £7–10m per quarter overnight…. what’s being said is that the trajectory has changed…. higher production, better realised prices, lower costs and active restructuring are all moving in the right direction…. That’s progress…. and it’s exactly what you want to see from a company that’s been in suspension and is working its way back….

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Where discussion often goes off track is treating suspension as evidence of terminal failure rather than a mechanism to protect value while the company sorts out restructuring…. The latest RNS shows production has increased materially post-workover, which directly strengthens the company’s ability to satisfy creditor requirements and move toward resolution of outstanding reporting and governance matters…. Higher production at current gas prices isn’t hypothetical — it’s a current operational fact being reported to the market…. That means stronger cash generation and a far better starting point than the flat-lined or declining production people here keep assuming…. Even if gas prices moderate from current highs, improved production and lower costs still provide significantly more operational cash than before…. That’s exactly the sort of fundamental improvement that de-risks suspension outcomes…. Using worst-case reservoir decline and short “honeymoon” narratives as if they’re the only possible trajectory ignores the actual RNS figures…. No one is saying suspension should be lifted instantly, but the business is making measurable progress toward the thresholds that ultimately do matter in those suspension reviews….

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Bubblepoint, you’re making a lot of assumptions off incomplete information and then presenting the most negative interpretation as if it’s settled fact….. First, the latest RNS didn’t just point to a modest 15–20% uplift — it reported a material increase in production, well ahead of that range. That tells you optimisation is already delivering more than the low expectations you’re anchoring to….. Second, no one has claimed the current intervention is a “permanent fix” in isolation. It’s one step in a wider optimisation programme. Coil tubing, acidisation, flowback management and drawdown control are standard tools to reset well performance and maximise near-term cash generation — which is exactly what Angus needs right now….. The key point you keep overlooking is that Angus no longer requires a perfect reservoir outcome. Higher production today at current gas prices materially improves cash flow, strengthens the balance sheet, and changes the dynamics with creditors. That alone reduces risk versus the situation twelve months ago….. As for gas prices, yes they fluctuate — but the company is producing now into a stronger pricing environment, not modelling distant hypotheticals. Cash in the bank today matters more than speculative decline curves six months out….. Could production moderate over time? Of course. But starting from a significantly higher base, with ongoing optimisation and lower costs, puts Angus in a far better position than the “inevitable failure” scenario you keep repeating….. The latest RNS shows progress, not deterioration. Ignoring that and defaulting to worst-case outcomes doesn’t reflect what’s actually being reported…..

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Worth grounding this discussion in the latest RNS rather than hypotheticals….. the most recent update confirmed a very material increase in production following the workover, and that’s a real, reported step-change rather than forum speculation….. At this early stage of optimisation, seeing output at these levels is encouraging. No one is claiming this is the final stabilised rate, but starting from a much higher base fundamentally improves the economics. Even a moderation from recent highs still leaves production well ahead of where Angus was operating previously….. Crucially, the company no longer needs heroic assumptions. Higher production at current gas prices translates into strong near-term cash generation, covering opex and materially strengthening the balance sheet. That shifts discussions with creditors and lenders onto far firmer ground than last year….. Yes, reservoir management and decline are always factors, but optimisation is ongoing and the field is delivering today. The narrative that this is all temporary or destined to fail doesn’t align with the actual data being released….. Momentum matters. Rising production, improving cash flow, lower costs, and restructuring discussions backed by operational progress are exactly what the market needs to see. If this trajectory continues, the outlook looks meaningfully better than the constant worst-case scenarios being repeated here…..

data.author: Mirasol
data.content: As BP keeps pointing out  the liquids drop out due the pressure/temperature conditions in the reservoir.  This will continue and can only get worse as you produce more and the reservoir pressure continues to drop. If they have only done a simple acid wash (which appears to be the case) all they've done is to clean up some of the pathways inbetweeen the rock grains near the well bore.  That should lead to a short-term uptick in gas production as gas  will be able to flow more easily to the well.  However it doesn't change the physics.    Fluids will continue to drop out, and if they pull too hard that will eventually totally impede any gas flow.  The well will choke itself to death.  Even a new well will suffer the same problems - unless they can identify a part of the field that has so far been untapped and has near original pressures.  There is zero evidence that this is the case or  that  ANGS have the knowledge or ability to identify such an area should it exist.

data.author: Bubblepoint
data.content: ""Does this intervention not provide a permanent solution to flushing out the liquids?"" The problem with the information this shower of sheite provides, is that it is very limited on detail. BUT from what they HAVE supplied, it pretty much indicates that they are NOT installing velocity strings as part of the workover, it is JUST a simple coil tubing intervention, to pump acid and then to flow out wellbore and near wellbore BANKED liquids and backflow the acid cleanup fluids. Once this has been flushed out, it appears the wells will simply go back on to production as before. WHICH is sheite, because it WILL result in simply inducing MORE liquids and the choking off of free gas continues... So expect an uplift in overall production, of around 15-20% overall, with a short honeymoon period, before a slow continued decline due to those liquids accumulating. Ultimately, it will not bring in the production needed to bail this shower out of the defaulted debt sinkhole they are in, unless gas prices rally and stay at 150p +, which is ALSO unlikely as demand season is quickly coming to an end !!

data.author: HeadInTheSand
data.content: As before, we still don't have the information needed. In terms of senior creditors, ANGS owes Trafigura around £29 million (capital plus annual interest @ 12%). It owes PF around £2 million for the original SFBY purchase. It owes Mercuria and Aleph around £3 million on the eternal 8% ORRI that it's also never paid to date. I honestly forget if there are any other large sums owed - I may well have forgotten remaining amounts to settle previous hedge contracts - but let's go with the £34 million above as a starting point. So... for the last 8+ months, it's been "renegotiating" with Trafigura. We still don't know the terms that Trafigura will impose (and ANGS will have no choice but to accept... or go pop, as per the going concern language in all recent RNSes). Once those are known and there's clearer sight on ANGS's regular opex expenditure and also any future short- to mid-term capex needs, then we'll see what level of post capex/opex monthly revenue ANGS will be required to generate in order to meet the terms of any new refinancing, how possible that is, and what if anything will be left over. Without knowing that stuff, any speculation is pointless.

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Calling something “technically in default” doesn’t make it so. Default is declared by the lender, not by anonymous posters repeating the word louder each time. Trafigura has not declared default, therefore there is no default, no matter how many times the phrase is recycled for effect.………What actually matters is current reality, not selective history. Angus is producing, debt is defined, repayments are being negotiated, and the lender remains engaged. Penalties and runaway interest are a fiction; outstanding items relate to capital structure, not some mythical sinkhole expanding by the minute. That distinction is inconvenient for derampers, but it’s fundamental.………Suspension is about resolution and clarity, not collapse. When Angus returns with terms, production stability and forward visibility, the same voices shouting “default” today will quietly disappear or pretend they always expected a rerate. The market will judge on cash flow and structure, not forum theatrics.

data.author: HeadInTheSand
data.content: Mirasol correctly says "The only real guide we have is when they said trhey wre paying the trade creditors but not the finacing debts. I wonder how fast that debt is actually increasing - it must be horrific by now after 9++ months." Re the most senior creditor (Trafigura), the current terms of its loan are:- £20m on a 5 year fixed term (from end Feb 2024). No capital or interest repayments required in Year One. 20 quarterly capital repayments of £1.25m required starting end Mar 2025. Interest rate of 12% per annum (SONIA + 8%). We know that no capital repayments were made at either Mar 25 or Jun 25, because ANGS didn't have the cash at the time. So after  Year One (the grace year) ANGS would have owed £20m of capital and £2.23m of interest, totalling £22.23m pounds. Presuming they've so far paid nothing back, £22.23m over now four years will attract 16 quarterly repayments of £1.39m plus a total of £5.87m of interest, totalling £28m.

data.author: ocelot
data.content: Balcombe (25% Working Interest) ... The decision of the High Court was made public on 16 April 2025 and ruled in favour of the Company. The Company is now evaluating options for the extended well test. Lidsey (80% Working Interest) Due to the high cost of water disposal, Lidsey has remained shut in, however, as previously stated, a planning application has been submitted to allow for transportation of produced water off-site to the Brockham oil field for voidage replacement and pressure maintenance. This application has now been approved, and we are awaiting imminent formal validation. Once received, the Company will progress to test the integrity of the well in readiness for future production, confirm the operability of the currently installed artificial lift, and establish the re-instatement production potential of the X2 well. This is low-cost operation, and if successful, it will allow for the reinstatement of the site with produced water trucked to Brockham for injection.
data.thread_title: Balcombe, Lidsey, from the interim results RNS of 30/06/25

data.author: ocelot
data.content: UK natural gas futures fell more than 12% to below 83 pence a therm, retreating from a ten-month high of 103.7 hit on January 21, as concerns over LNG supply eased. Near term US weather forecasts turned milder, reducing heating demand and allowing more gas to flow to LNG export plants, improving the outlook for deliveries to Europe and the UK. The UK remains highly sensitive due to limited storage capacity and heavy reliance on imports, making it vulnerable to regional and global supply pressures. Geopolitical risk premiums also faded after US President Donald Trump said Washington is in talks with Iran, easing fears of disruptions to shipping through the Strait of Hormuz. Still, underlying vulnerability remains, with EU gas storage at just 41.1% full and UK storage around 36.9%. https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/uk-natural-gas

data.content: Bubblepoint, this constant attempt to sound “balanced” while leaning relentlessly negative is getting a bit transparent…… You shout “SELECTIVE” every time someone posts hard production data…… yet you’re perfectly happy to cherry-pick gas price pullbacks, intraday share moves and macro noise as if they somehow invalidate field performance…… That isn’t balance…… that’s just selective pessimism dressed up as realism…… Gas prices move…… equities move…… everyone here knows that…… what actually matters to Angus is whether the asset can flow at materially higher rates once the workover programme completes…… And inconveniently for the deramp narrative, the highest production days since September 2024 appeared during the intervention period…… which strongly suggests improved underlying capability, not deterioration…… You keep implying the company “never pays anything” and everything is smoke and mirrors…… yet the same company is actively executing, funding operations, and progressing a defined programme with clear timelines…… not exactly the behaviour of something “done”…… March will bring clarity…… January has already brought confirmation the wells can deliver when flowing…… pretending otherwise doesn’t make it less true…… Short-term volatility is noise…… operational progress is signal…… If you genuinely believe Angus has no future, that’s fine…… but repeatedly hammering the same negative macro talking points into a production thread doesn’t make them more relevant — just louder……

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Stepping back and looking at the overall posts, the picture is actually pretty constructive…… We’ve got clear evidence that when the field is flowing, it can deliver the best rates seen since September 2024…… that matters, regardless of how fashionable it is to downplay it…… Yes, there’s downtime…… there always is in any producing field, especially during a planned workover phase…… none of this is new, unexpected, or unforecast…… What is new is confirmation that post-intervention flow potential is materially higher than the baseline…… and that’s exactly what the programme was designed to test…… Quoting guidance while dismissing live data doesn’t invalidate the data…… it just delays acknowledging it…… lenders, operators, and markets all ultimately care about what the wells actually produce…… The 30-day average provides balance…… the recent daily figures provide direction…… taken together, they suggest variability in the short term but improving capability underneath…… Which is why the sensible approach here is patience, not pessimism…… March will give clarity, but January has already given reassurance…… Short-term noise fades…… capacity doesn’t……

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: A lot of the negativity in this thread relies on ignoring what Angus has actually reported via RNS and instead repeating worst-case assumptions as if they are facts. Saltfleetby is a producing UK gas field generating real revenue today, not a hypothetical asset or a story stock ….. The most recent updates confirmed materially higher gas sales in Q4 2025, with revenue north of £4m for the quarter. This came from improved uptime and optimisation, not a one-off spike. Production has stabilised and that directly improves cash generation, which is the only thing that ultimately matters ….. Legacy low-price hedges have now largely rolled off, meaning a much greater proportion of production is being sold at prevailing market prices. Valuing the field as if those old hedges are permanent is simply outdated. Margins today are meaningfully better than they were even six months ago ….. Claims that the company has “no cash” or “no options” also ignore the fact that Angus has been operating for an extended period with limited capex while creditor discussions continue. Lenders are rational actors and benefit far more from supporting a producing asset than forcing failure. That reality is why restructuring talks are ongoing ….. Finally, writing off Saltfleetby as having no future value beyond immediate production shows a lack of perspective. Depleted gas fields with infrastructure and grid access have strategic importance in the UK. Whether people like management or not is irrelevant — the asset has value, and the current market price reflects sentiment, not fundamentals …..

data.author: Sufc100
data.content: As of January 2026, the Saltfleetby Gas Field (wholly owned by Angus Energy) has an estimated going-concern valuation of £55 million to £65 million. This valuation is based on the most recent Competent Persons Report (CPR) and 2025/2026 financial updates. The field is the UK’s largest onshore gas producer and its value is derived from three main areas: 1. Asset Valuation (NPV10) According to the technical audits, the "Net Present Value" (discounted at 10%) of the field’s future cash flows is: P90 (Low Estimate): £57.1 million P50 (Best Estimate): £64.5 million Note: These figures are post-tax and already account for the UK government's Energy Profits Levy (Windfall Tax). 2. Revenue and Production (Going Concern) The field is currently a high-performing "cash cow" for Angus Energy. In the most recent trading update (issued January 22, 2026), the field showed: Quarterly Revenue: £4.12 million (for Q4 2025). Annualized Revenue: Approximately £16 million – £20 million depending on seasonal gas prices. Output: Producing roughly 1.66 million therms of gas per month. 3. Future "Upside" Value Beyond current gas extraction, the field holds significant value for its potential after the gas is gone: Gas Storage: It is considered one of the best candidates in the UK for conversion into a hydrogen storage facility or for Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS). This adds "strategic value" that isn't fully captured in the current £65m gas valuation. New Drilling: Two new wells (SF9 and SF10) were scheduled for 2025 and early 2026 to maintain production "plateau" and accelerate gas extraction. Summary of "Going Concern" Health While the asset itself is valuable, the "going concern" status of the parent company (Angus Energy) was under review in late 2025 due to debt restructuring. However, the January 2026 update indicates a strong recovery, with production surging and legacy low-price "hedges" finally ending, allowing the company to sell gas at full market prices (approx. 102p per therm).

The field is the UK’s largest onshore gas producer and its value is derived from three main areas: 1. Asset Valuation (NPV10) According to the technical audits, the "Net Present Value" (discounted at 10%) of the field’s future cash flows is: P90 (Low Estimate): £57.1 million P50 (Best Estimate): £64.5 million Note: These figures are post-tax and already account for the UK government's Energy Profits Levy (Windfall Tax). 2. Revenue and Production (Going Concern) The field is currently a high-performing "cash cow" for Angus Energy. In the most recent trading update (issued January 22, 2026), the field showed: Quarterly Revenue: £4.12 million (for Q4 2025). Annualized Revenue: Approximately £16 million – £20 million depending on seasonal gas prices. Output: Producing roughly 1.66 million therms of gas per month. 3. Future "Upside" Value Beyond current gas extraction, the field holds significant value for its potential after the gas is gone: Gas Storage: It is considered one of the best candidates in the UK for conversion into a hydrogen storage facility or for Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS). This adds "strategic value" that isn't fully captured in the current £65m gas valuation. New Drilling: Two new wells (SF9 and SF10) were scheduled for 2025 and early 2026 to maintain production "plateau" and accelerate gas extraction. Summary of "Going Concern" Health While the asset itself is valuable, the "going concern" status of the parent company (Angus Energy) was under review in late 2025 due to debt restructuring. However, the January 2026 update indicates a strong recovery, with production surging and legacy low-price "hedges" finally ending, allowing the company to sell gas at full market prices (approx. 102p per therm).

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Bubblepoint, you’re conflating two different things deliberately or otherwise…. RNSs are not meant to read like investor presentations or broker models…. they are regulatory disclosures, and by design they don’t include forward guidance, speculative cash forecasts, or granular commercial negotiations…. That doesn’t make the facts that are disclosed meaningless…. £30m total debt is a fact…. the workover being funded from cash is a fact…. materially higher production post-workover is a fact…. lower opex versus last year is a fact…. and legacy hedges rolling off into a stronger pricing environment is also a fact…. You keep saying “no facts” while ignoring the ones that don’t fit your narrative…. then you fall back on history as if companies are not allowed to change trajectory after restructuring…. that’s analysis anchored in the past, not what’s happening now…. No one here is claiming RNSs tell the entire story…. but they don’t need to…. what matters is direction of travel, and that direction has clearly improved compared with where Angus was heading into default last year…. Cash generation improving, costs down, production up, and debt being restructured at lower rates is not a “wet dream”…. it’s a stabilisation phase…. and stabilisation is exactly what precedes rerating in situations like this…. You’re free to remain sceptical…. but dismissing every positive development as fiction doesn’t make it so…. it just means you’re choosing not to engage with the facts that are already on the table….

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Bubblepoint, you keep reframing every development as a negative regardless of what the RNS actually says…. that might suit a narrative, but it doesn’t reflect what’s being reported…. Calling the recent production uplift a “rabbit out of the hat” ignores the fact that Saltfleetby has always been capable of higher rates once constraints were addressed…. the latest RNS confirms a material improvement following the workover, not some cosmetic bounce…. On the share count point, yes there are a lot of shares in issue…. that’s already well known and fully reflected in the price…. what changes outcomes isn’t the historical capital structure, it’s cash generation and balance sheet repair, and that’s exactly where things are improving…. As for the “new well” scepticism, nobody is pretending it’s risk-free or imminent tomorrow…. the point is that higher current production and stronger margins give Angus options they simply didn’t have before…. optionality matters when a company is coming out of a stressed period…. You also keep anchoring to falling gas prices as if that’s a certainty…. prices fluctuate, but Angus is producing now, into a materially better pricing environment than most of 2024, with legacy hedges rolling off and a much leaner cost base…. that combination is what improves margins, not a single headline price…. No one sensible is saying this is a guaranteed straight line to £7–10m per quarter overnight…. what’s being said is that the trajectory has changed…. higher production, better realised prices, lower costs and active restructuring are all moving in the right direction…. That’s progress…. and it’s exactly what you want to see from a company that’s been in suspension and is working its way back….

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Where discussion often goes off track is treating suspension as evidence of terminal failure rather than a mechanism to protect value while the company sorts out restructuring…. The latest RNS shows production has increased materially post-workover, which directly strengthens the company’s ability to satisfy creditor requirements and move toward resolution of outstanding reporting and governance matters…. Higher production at current gas prices isn’t hypothetical — it’s a current operational fact being reported to the market…. That means stronger cash generation and a far better starting point than the flat-lined or declining production people here keep assuming…. Even if gas prices moderate from current highs, improved production and lower costs still provide significantly more operational cash than before…. That’s exactly the sort of fundamental improvement that de-risks suspension outcomes…. Using worst-case reservoir decline and short “honeymoon” narratives as if they’re the only possible trajectory ignores the actual RNS figures…. No one is saying suspension should be lifted instantly, but the business is making measurable progress toward the thresholds that ultimately do matter in those suspension reviews….

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Bubblepoint, you’re making a lot of assumptions off incomplete information and then presenting the most negative interpretation as if it’s settled fact….. First, the latest RNS didn’t just point to a modest 15–20% uplift — it reported a material increase in production, well ahead of that range. That tells you optimisation is already delivering more than the low expectations you’re anchoring to….. Second, no one has claimed the current intervention is a “permanent fix” in isolation. It’s one step in a wider optimisation programme. Coil tubing, acidisation, flowback management and drawdown control are standard tools to reset well performance and maximise near-term cash generation — which is exactly what Angus needs right now….. The key point you keep overlooking is that Angus no longer requires a perfect reservoir outcome. Higher production today at current gas prices materially improves cash flow, strengthens the balance sheet, and changes the dynamics with creditors. That alone reduces risk versus the situation twelve months ago….. As for gas prices, yes they fluctuate — but the company is producing now into a stronger pricing environment, not modelling distant hypotheticals. Cash in the bank today matters more than speculative decline curves six months out….. Could production moderate over time? Of course. But starting from a significantly higher base, with ongoing optimisation and lower costs, puts Angus in a far better position than the “inevitable failure” scenario you keep repeating….. The latest RNS shows progress, not deterioration. Ignoring that and defaulting to worst-case outcomes doesn’t reflect what’s actually being reported…..

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Worth grounding this discussion in the latest RNS rather than hypotheticals….. the most recent update confirmed a very material increase in production following the workover, and that’s a real, reported step-change rather than forum speculation….. At this early stage of optimisation, seeing output at these levels is encouraging. No one is claiming this is the final stabilised rate, but starting from a much higher base fundamentally improves the economics. Even a moderation from recent highs still leaves production well ahead of where Angus was operating previously….. Crucially, the company no longer needs heroic assumptions. Higher production at current gas prices translates into strong near-term cash generation, covering opex and materially strengthening the balance sheet. That shifts discussions with creditors and lenders onto far firmer ground than last year….. Yes, reservoir management and decline are always factors, but optimisation is ongoing and the field is delivering today. The narrative that this is all temporary or destined to fail doesn’t align with the actual data being released….. Momentum matters. Rising production, improving cash flow, lower costs, and restructuring discussions backed by operational progress are exactly what the market needs to see. If this trajectory continues, the outlook looks meaningfully better than the constant worst-case scenarios being repeated here…..

data.author: Mirasol
data.content: As BP keeps pointing out  the liquids drop out due the pressure/temperature conditions in the reservoir.  This will continue and can only get worse as you produce more and the reservoir pressure continues to drop. If they have only done a simple acid wash (which appears to be the case) all they've done is to clean up some of the pathways inbetweeen the rock grains near the well bore.  That should lead to a short-term uptick in gas production as gas  will be able to flow more easily to the well.  However it doesn't change the physics.    Fluids will continue to drop out, and if they pull too hard that will eventually totally impede any gas flow.  The well will choke itself to death.  Even a new well will suffer the same problems - unless they can identify a part of the field that has so far been untapped and has near original pressures.  There is zero evidence that this is the case or  that  ANGS have the knowledge or ability to identify such an area should it exist.

data.author: Bubblepoint
data.content: ""Does this intervention not provide a permanent solution to flushing out the liquids?"" The problem with the information this shower of sheite provides, is that it is very limited on detail. BUT from what they HAVE supplied, it pretty much indicates that they are NOT installing velocity strings as part of the workover, it is JUST a simple coil tubing intervention, to pump acid and then to flow out wellbore and near wellbore BANKED liquids and backflow the acid cleanup fluids. Once this has been flushed out, it appears the wells will simply go back on to production as before. WHICH is sheite, because it WILL result in simply inducing MORE liquids and the choking off of free gas continues... So expect an uplift in overall production, of around 15-20% overall, with a short honeymoon period, before a slow continued decline due to those liquids accumulating. Ultimately, it will not bring in the production needed to bail this shower out of the defaulted debt sinkhole they are in, unless gas prices rally and stay at 150p +, which is ALSO unlikely as demand season is quickly coming to an end !!

data.author: HeadInTheSand
data.content: As before, we still don't have the information needed. In terms of senior creditors, ANGS owes Trafigura around £29 million (capital plus annual interest @ 12%). It owes PF around £2 million for the original SFBY purchase. It owes Mercuria and Aleph around £3 million on the eternal 8% ORRI that it's also never paid to date. I honestly forget if there are any other large sums owed - I may well have forgotten remaining amounts to settle previous hedge contracts - but let's go with the £34 million above as a starting point. So... for the last 8+ months, it's been "renegotiating" with Trafigura. We still don't know the terms that Trafigura will impose (and ANGS will have no choice but to accept... or go pop, as per the going concern language in all recent RNSes). Once those are known and there's clearer sight on ANGS's regular opex expenditure and also any future short- to mid-term capex needs, then we'll see what level of post capex/opex monthly revenue ANGS will be required to generate in order to meet the terms of any new refinancing, how possible that is, and what if anything will be left over. Without knowing that stuff, any speculation is pointless.

data.author: WG818
data.content: Expected decline from here (end‑of‑life field) Assuming a post‑clean‑up plateau of ~0.13–0.15 mscm/d: Months 0–12: Hold roughly 0.13–0.15 mscm/d (SF2 + SF7 doing the work, SF4 marginal). Months 12–24: Drop to around 0.10–0.13 mscm/d as liquids build and drawdown bites. Months 24–36: Likely sub‑0.10 mscm/d, with more downtime, more cycling, and only short‑lived bumps from any further interventions. Big picture: You get maybe 6–12 months of half‑decent rates, then a managed glide down as a tired, end‑of‑life asset.

data.author: WG818
data.content: I’ve been keeping an eye on the daily production figures and asked AI for some input. It’s come up with the following after some pertinent questions from myself with years of experience here. Saltfleetby – Post‑Workover Reality Check SF4 hasn’t been worked over and is still the most liquids‑prone well. Realistic output is only 0.02–0.04 mscm/d. SF2 has been cleaned up and is now giving a steady 0.05–0.06 mscm/d. SF7 is the big swing factor. The brief 0.18 mscm/d spike shows all three wells can hit that level, but SF7 clearly isn’t stable yet and has been mostly offline for the last two weeks. The current flat 0.09–0.10 mscm/d is simply SF2 + SF4 while SF7 is still being managed. Liquids storage is now a hard surface bottleneck. Even if the wells could push higher, the site can’t run flat‑out without overloading tanks and causing slugging. Realistic sustained rate after full clean‑up: ≈ 0.13–0.15 mscm/d (with occasional short peaks up to 0.17–0.18 mscm/d when storage allows) Bottom line: The field will likely settle around 0.13–0.15 mscm/d once SF7 is properly back, because the limiting factor is now liquids handling, not the reservoir.

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Calling something “technically in default” doesn’t make it so. Default is declared by the lender, not by anonymous posters repeating the word louder each time. Trafigura has not declared default, therefore there is no default, no matter how many times the phrase is recycled for effect.………What actually matters is current reality, not selective history. Angus is producing, debt is defined, repayments are being negotiated, and the lender remains engaged. Penalties and runaway interest are a fiction; outstanding items relate to capital structure, not some mythical sinkhole expanding by the minute. That distinction is inconvenient for derampers, but it’s fundamental.………Suspension is about resolution and clarity, not collapse. When Angus returns with terms, production stability and forward visibility, the same voices shouting “default” today will quietly disappear or pretend they always expected a rerate. The market will judge on cash flow and structure, not forum theatrics.

data.author: HeadInTheSand
data.content: Mirasol correctly says "The only real guide we have is when they said trhey wre paying the trade creditors but not the finacing debts. I wonder how fast that debt is actually increasing - it must be horrific by now after 9++ months." Re the most senior creditor (Trafigura), the current terms of its loan are:- £20m on a 5 year fixed term (from end Feb 2024). No capital or interest repayments required in Year One. 20 quarterly capital repayments of £1.25m required starting end Mar 2025. Interest rate of 12% per annum (SONIA + 8%). We know that no capital repayments were made at either Mar 25 or Jun 25, because ANGS didn't have the cash at the time. So after  Year One (the grace year) ANGS would have owed £20m of capital and £2.23m of interest, totalling £22.23m pounds. Presuming they've so far paid nothing back, £22.23m over now four years will attract 16 quarterly repayments of £1.39m plus a total of £5.87m of interest, totalling £28m.

data.author: ocelot
data.content: Balcombe (25% Working Interest) ... The decision of the High Court was made public on 16 April 2025 and ruled in favour of the Company. The Company is now evaluating options for the extended well test. Lidsey (80% Working Interest) Due to the high cost of water disposal, Lidsey has remained shut in, however, as previously stated, a planning application has been submitted to allow for transportation of produced water off-site to the Brockham oil field for voidage replacement and pressure maintenance. This application has now been approved, and we are awaiting imminent formal validation. Once received, the Company will progress to test the integrity of the well in readiness for future production, confirm the operability of the currently installed artificial lift, and establish the re-instatement production potential of the X2 well. This is low-cost operation, and if successful, it will allow for the reinstatement of the site with produced water trucked to Brockham for injection.

data.author: ocelot
data.content: UK natural gas futures fell more than 12% to below 83 pence a therm, retreating from a ten-month high of 103.7 hit on January 21, as concerns over LNG supply eased. Near term US weather forecasts turned milder, reducing heating demand and allowing more gas to flow to LNG export plants, improving the outlook for deliveries to Europe and the UK. The UK remains highly sensitive due to limited storage capacity and heavy reliance on imports, making it vulnerable to regional and global supply pressures. Geopolitical risk premiums also faded after US President Donald Trump said Washington is in talks with Iran, easing fears of disruptions to shipping through the Strait of Hormuz. Still, underlying vulnerability remains, with EU gas storage at just 41.1% full and UK storage around 36.9%. https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/uk-natural-gas
data.thread_title: Market prices (written yesterday but covers principal themes)

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Stepping back and looking at the overall posts, the picture is actually pretty constructive…… We’ve got clear evidence that when the field is flowing, it can deliver the best rates seen since September 2024…… that matters, regardless of how fashionable it is to downplay it…… Yes, there’s downtime…… there always is in any producing field, especially during a planned workover phase…… none of this is new, unexpected, or unforecast…… What is new is confirmation that post-intervention flow potential is materially higher than the baseline…… and that’s exactly what the programme was designed to test…… Quoting guidance while dismissing live data doesn’t invalidate the data…… it just delays acknowledging it…… lenders, operators, and markets all ultimately care about what the wells actually produce…… The 30-day average provides balance…… the recent daily figures provide direction…… taken together, they suggest variability in the short term but improving capability underneath…… Which is why the sensible approach here is patience, not pessimism…… March will give clarity, but January has already given reassurance…… Short-term noise fades…… capacity doesn’t……

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: A lot of the negativity in this thread relies on ignoring what Angus has actually reported via RNS and instead repeating worst-case assumptions as if they are facts. Saltfleetby is a producing UK gas field generating real revenue today, not a hypothetical asset or a story stock ….. The most recent updates confirmed materially higher gas sales in Q4 2025, with revenue north of £4m for the quarter. This came from improved uptime and optimisation, not a one-off spike. Production has stabilised and that directly improves cash generation, which is the only thing that ultimately matters ….. Legacy low-price hedges have now largely rolled off, meaning a much greater proportion of production is being sold at prevailing market prices. Valuing the field as if those old hedges are permanent is simply outdated. Margins today are meaningfully better than they were even six months ago ….. Claims that the company has “no cash” or “no options” also ignore the fact that Angus has been operating for an extended period with limited capex while creditor discussions continue. Lenders are rational actors and benefit far more from supporting a producing asset than forcing failure. That reality is why restructuring talks are ongoing ….. Finally, writing off Saltfleetby as having no future value beyond immediate production shows a lack of perspective. Depleted gas fields with infrastructure and grid access have strategic importance in the UK. Whether people like management or not is irrelevant — the asset has value, and the current market price reflects sentiment, not fundamentals …..

data.author: Sufc100
data.content: As of January 2026, the Saltfleetby Gas Field (wholly owned by Angus Energy) has an estimated going-concern valuation of £55 million to £65 million. This valuation is based on the most recent Competent Persons Report (CPR) and 2025/2026 financial updates. The field is the UK’s largest onshore gas producer and its value is derived from three main areas: 1. Asset Valuation (NPV10) According to the technical audits, the "Net Present Value" (discounted at 10%) of the field’s future cash flows is: P90 (Low Estimate): £57.1 million P50 (Best Estimate): £64.5 million Note: These figures are post-tax and already account for the UK government's Energy Profits Levy (Windfall Tax). 2. Revenue and Production (Going Concern) The field is currently a high-performing "cash cow" for Angus Energy. In the most recent trading update (issued January 22, 2026), the field showed: Quarterly Revenue: £4.12 million (for Q4 2025). Annualized Revenue: Approximately £16 million – £20 million depending on seasonal gas prices. Output: Producing roughly 1.66 million therms of gas per month. 3. Future "Upside" Value Beyond current gas extraction, the field holds significant value for its potential after the gas is gone: Gas Storage: It is considered one of the best candidates in the UK for conversion into a hydrogen storage facility or for Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS). This adds "strategic value" that isn't fully captured in the current £65m gas valuation. New Drilling: Two new wells (SF9 and SF10) were scheduled for 2025 and early 2026 to maintain production "plateau" and accelerate gas extraction. Summary of "Going Concern" Health While the asset itself is valuable, the "going concern" status of the parent company (Angus Energy) was under review in late 2025 due to debt restructuring. However, the January 2026 update indicates a strong recovery, with production surging and legacy low-price "hedges" finally ending, allowing the company to sell gas at full market prices (approx. 102p per therm).

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Bubblepoint, you’re conflating two different things deliberately or otherwise…. RNSs are not meant to read like investor presentations or broker models…. they are regulatory disclosures, and by design they don’t include forward guidance, speculative cash forecasts, or granular commercial negotiations…. That doesn’t make the facts that are disclosed meaningless…. £30m total debt is a fact…. the workover being funded from cash is a fact…. materially higher production post-workover is a fact…. lower opex versus last year is a fact…. and legacy hedges rolling off into a stronger pricing environment is also a fact…. You keep saying “no facts” while ignoring the ones that don’t fit your narrative…. then you fall back on history as if companies are not allowed to change trajectory after restructuring…. that’s analysis anchored in the past, not what’s happening now…. No one here is claiming RNSs tell the entire story…. but they don’t need to…. what matters is direction of travel, and that direction has clearly improved compared with where Angus was heading into default last year…. Cash generation improving, costs down, production up, and debt being restructured at lower rates is not a “wet dream”…. it’s a stabilisation phase…. and stabilisation is exactly what precedes rerating in situations like this…. You’re free to remain sceptical…. but dismissing every positive development as fiction doesn’t make it so…. it just means you’re choosing not to engage with the facts that are already on the table….

On the share count point, yes there are a lot of shares in issue…. that’s already well known and fully reflected in the price…. what changes outcomes isn’t the historical capital structure, it’s cash generation and balance sheet repair, and that’s exactly where things are improving…. As for the “new well” scepticism, nobody is pretending it’s risk-free or imminent tomorrow…. the point is that higher current production and stronger margins give Angus options they simply didn’t have before…. optionality matters when a company is coming out of a stressed period…. You also keep anchoring to falling gas prices as if that’s a certainty…. prices fluctuate, but Angus is producing now, into a materially better pricing environment than most of 2024, with legacy hedges rolling off and a much leaner cost base…. that combination is what improves margins, not a single headline price…. No one sensible is saying this is a guaranteed straight line to £7–10m per quarter overnight…. what’s being said is that the trajectory has changed…. higher production, better realised prices, lower costs and active restructuring are all moving in the right direction…. That’s progress…. and it’s exactly what you want to see from a company that’s been in suspension and is working its way back….

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Where discussion often goes off track is treating suspension as evidence of terminal failure rather than a mechanism to protect value while the company sorts out restructuring…. The latest RNS shows production has increased materially post-workover, which directly strengthens the company’s ability to satisfy creditor requirements and move toward resolution of outstanding reporting and governance matters…. Higher production at current gas prices isn’t hypothetical — it’s a current operational fact being reported to the market…. That means stronger cash generation and a far better starting point than the flat-lined or declining production people here keep assuming…. Even if gas prices moderate from current highs, improved production and lower costs still provide significantly more operational cash than before…. That’s exactly the sort of fundamental improvement that de-risks suspension outcomes…. Using worst-case reservoir decline and short “honeymoon” narratives as if they’re the only possible trajectory ignores the actual RNS figures…. No one is saying suspension should be lifted instantly, but the business is making measurable progress toward the thresholds that ultimately do matter in those suspension reviews….

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Bubblepoint, you’re making a lot of assumptions off incomplete information and then presenting the most negative interpretation as if it’s settled fact….. First, the latest RNS didn’t just point to a modest 15–20% uplift — it reported a material increase in production, well ahead of that range. That tells you optimisation is already delivering more than the low expectations you’re anchoring to….. Second, no one has claimed the current intervention is a “permanent fix” in isolation. It’s one step in a wider optimisation programme. Coil tubing, acidisation, flowback management and drawdown control are standard tools to reset well performance and maximise near-term cash generation — which is exactly what Angus needs right now….. The key point you keep overlooking is that Angus no longer requires a perfect reservoir outcome. Higher production today at current gas prices materially improves cash flow, strengthens the balance sheet, and changes the dynamics with creditors. That alone reduces risk versus the situation twelve months ago….. As for gas prices, yes they fluctuate — but the company is producing now into a stronger pricing environment, not modelling distant hypotheticals. Cash in the bank today matters more than speculative decline curves six months out….. Could production moderate over time? Of course. But starting from a significantly higher base, with ongoing optimisation and lower costs, puts Angus in a far better position than the “inevitable failure” scenario you keep repeating….. The latest RNS shows progress, not deterioration. Ignoring that and defaulting to worst-case outcomes doesn’t reflect what’s actually being reported…..

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Worth grounding this discussion in the latest RNS rather than hypotheticals….. the most recent update confirmed a very material increase in production following the workover, and that’s a real, reported step-change rather than forum speculation….. At this early stage of optimisation, seeing output at these levels is encouraging. No one is claiming this is the final stabilised rate, but starting from a much higher base fundamentally improves the economics. Even a moderation from recent highs still leaves production well ahead of where Angus was operating previously….. Crucially, the company no longer needs heroic assumptions. Higher production at current gas prices translates into strong near-term cash generation, covering opex and materially strengthening the balance sheet. That shifts discussions with creditors and lenders onto far firmer ground than last year….. Yes, reservoir management and decline are always factors, but optimisation is ongoing and the field is delivering today. The narrative that this is all temporary or destined to fail doesn’t align with the actual data being released….. Momentum matters. Rising production, improving cash flow, lower costs, and restructuring discussions backed by operational progress are exactly what the market needs to see. If this trajectory continues, the outlook looks meaningfully better than the constant worst-case scenarios being repeated here…..

data.author: Mirasol
data.content: As BP keeps pointing out  the liquids drop out due the pressure/temperature conditions in the reservoir.  This will continue and can only get worse as you produce more and the reservoir pressure continues to drop. If they have only done a simple acid wash (which appears to be the case) all they've done is to clean up some of the pathways inbetweeen the rock grains near the well bore.  That should lead to a short-term uptick in gas production as gas  will be able to flow more easily to the well.  However it doesn't change the physics.    Fluids will continue to drop out, and if they pull too hard that will eventually totally impede any gas flow.  The well will choke itself to death.  Even a new well will suffer the same problems - unless they can identify a part of the field that has so far been untapped and has near original pressures.  There is zero evidence that this is the case or  that  ANGS have the knowledge or ability to identify such an area should it exist.

data.author: Bubblepoint
data.content: ""Does this intervention not provide a permanent solution to flushing out the liquids?"" The problem with the information this shower of sheite provides, is that it is very limited on detail. BUT from what they HAVE supplied, it pretty much indicates that they are NOT installing velocity strings as part of the workover, it is JUST a simple coil tubing intervention, to pump acid and then to flow out wellbore and near wellbore BANKED liquids and backflow the acid cleanup fluids. Once this has been flushed out, it appears the wells will simply go back on to production as before. WHICH is sheite, because it WILL result in simply inducing MORE liquids and the choking off of free gas continues... So expect an uplift in overall production, of around 15-20% overall, with a short honeymoon period, before a slow continued decline due to those liquids accumulating. Ultimately, it will not bring in the production needed to bail this shower out of the defaulted debt sinkhole they are in, unless gas prices rally and stay at 150p +, which is ALSO unlikely as demand season is quickly coming to an end !!

data.author: HeadInTheSand
data.content: As before, we still don't have the information needed. In terms of senior creditors, ANGS owes Trafigura around £29 million (capital plus annual interest @ 12%). It owes PF around £2 million for the original SFBY purchase. It owes Mercuria and Aleph around £3 million on the eternal 8% ORRI that it's also never paid to date. I honestly forget if there are any other large sums owed - I may well have forgotten remaining amounts to settle previous hedge contracts - but let's go with the £34 million above as a starting point. So... for the last 8+ months, it's been "renegotiating" with Trafigura. We still don't know the terms that Trafigura will impose (and ANGS will have no choice but to accept... or go pop, as per the going concern language in all recent RNSes). Once those are known and there's clearer sight on ANGS's regular opex expenditure and also any future short- to mid-term capex needs, then we'll see what level of post capex/opex monthly revenue ANGS will be required to generate in order to meet the terms of any new refinancing, how possible that is, and what if anything will be left over. Without knowing that stuff, any speculation is pointless.

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Understood. Here it is with the …… explicitly used as a continuation link into the next paragraph. This drop is about UK gas prices, not Angus Energy as a business. Commodity prices have pulled back across the sector, dragging sentiment with them. That is macro, not company-specific.……Angus is a domestic gas producer, not a leveraged bet on geopolitics. Lower prices reduce upside temporarily; higher prices increase cash flow. That is how every commodity producer operates. ……Quoting percentage moves in a small-cap AIM stock proves nothing. Liquidity and weak hands drive volatility, not asset quality or operational reality.……Missing a Balcombe notice deadline does not mean planning consent is lost. The approval runs to February 2026. data.author: WG818
data.content: Expected decline from here (end‑of‑life field) Assuming a post‑clean‑up plateau of ~0.13–0.15 mscm/d: Months 0–12: Hold roughly 0.13–0.15 mscm/d (SF2 + SF7 doing the work, SF4 marginal). Months 12–24: Drop to around 0.10–0.13 mscm/d as liquids build and drawdown bites. Months 24–36: Likely sub‑0.10 mscm/d, with more downtime, more cycling, and only short‑lived bumps from any further interventions. Big picture: You get maybe 6–12 months of half‑decent rates, then a managed glide down as a tired, end‑of‑life asset.

data.author: WG818
data.content: I’ve been keeping an eye on the daily production figures and asked AI for some input. It’s come up with the following after some pertinent questions from myself with years of experience here. Saltfleetby – Post‑Workover Reality Check SF4 hasn’t been worked over and is still the most liquids‑prone well. Realistic output is only 0.02–0.04 mscm/d. SF2 has been cleaned up and is now giving a steady 0.05–0.06 mscm/d. SF7 is the big swing factor. The brief 0.18 mscm/d spike shows all three wells can hit that level, but SF7 clearly isn’t stable yet and has been mostly offline for the last two weeks. The current flat 0.09–0.10 mscm/d is simply SF2 + SF4 while SF7 is still being managed. Liquids storage is now a hard surface bottleneck. Even if the wells could push higher, the site can’t run flat‑out without overloading tanks and causing slugging. Realistic sustained rate after full clean‑up: ≈ 0.13–0.15 mscm/d (with occasional short peaks up to 0.17–0.18 mscm/d when storage allows) Bottom line: The field will likely settle around 0.13–0.15 mscm/d once SF7 is properly back, because the limiting factor is now liquids handling, not the reservoir.

data.author: HeadInTheSand
data.content: Mirasol correctly says "The only real guide we have is when they said trhey wre paying the trade creditors but not the finacing debts. I wonder how fast that debt is actually increasing - it must be horrific by now after 9++ months." Re the most senior creditor (Trafigura), the current terms of its loan are:- £20m on a 5 year fixed term (from end Feb 2024). No capital or interest repayments required in Year One. 20 quarterly capital repayments of £1.25m required starting end Mar 2025. Interest rate of 12% per annum (SONIA + 8%). We know that no capital repayments were made at either Mar 25 or Jun 25, because ANGS didn't have the cash at the time. So after  Year One (the grace year) ANGS would have owed £20m of capital and £2.23m of interest, totalling £22.23m pounds. Presuming they've so far paid nothing back, £22.23m over now four years will attract 16 quarterly repayments of £1.39m plus a total of £5.87m of interest, totalling £28m.

data.author: ocelot
data.content: Balcombe (25% Working Interest) ... The decision of the High Court was made public on 16 April 2025 and ruled in favour of the Company. The Company is now evaluating options for the extended well test. Lidsey (80% Working Interest) Due to the high cost of water disposal, Lidsey has remained shut in, however, as previously stated, a planning application has been submitted to allow for transportation of produced water off-site to the Brockham oil field for voidage replacement and pressure maintenance. This application has now been approved, and we are awaiting imminent formal validation. Once received, the Company will progress to test the integrity of the well in readiness for future production, confirm the operability of the currently installed artificial lift, and establish the re-instatement production potential of the X2 well. This is low-cost operation, and if successful, it will allow for the reinstatement of the site with produced water trucked to Brockham for injection.

data.author: ocelot
data.content: UK natural gas futures fell more than 12% to below 83 pence a therm, retreating from a ten-month high of 103.7 hit on January 21, as concerns over LNG supply eased. Near term US weather forecasts turned milder, reducing heating demand and allowing more gas to flow to LNG export plants, improving the outlook for deliveries to Europe and the UK. The UK remains highly sensitive due to limited storage capacity and heavy reliance on imports, making it vulnerable to regional and global supply pressures. Geopolitical risk premiums also faded after US President Donald Trump said Washington is in talks with Iran, easing fears of disruptions to shipping through the Strait of Hormuz. Still, underlying vulnerability remains, with EU gas storage at just 41.1% full and UK storage around 36.9%. https://tradingeconomics.com/commodity/uk-natural-gas

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Stepping back and looking at the overall posts, the picture is actually pretty constructive…… We’ve got clear evidence that when the field is flowing, it can deliver the best rates seen since September 2024…… that matters, regardless of how fashionable it is to downplay it…… Yes, there’s downtime…… there always is in any producing field, especially during a planned workover phase…… none of this is new, unexpected, or unforecast…… What is new is confirmation that post-intervention flow potential is materially higher than the baseline…… and that’s exactly what the programme was designed to test…… Quoting guidance while dismissing live data doesn’t invalidate the data…… it just delays acknowledging it…… lenders, operators, and markets all ultimately care about what the wells actually produce…… The 30-day average provides balance…… the recent daily figures provide direction…… taken together, they suggest variability in the short term but improving capability underneath…… Which is why the sensible approach here is patience, not pessimism…… March will give clarity, but January has already given reassurance…… Short-term noise fades…… capacity doesn’t……

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: A lot of the negativity in this thread relies on ignoring what Angus has actually reported via RNS and instead repeating worst-case assumptions as if they are facts. Saltfleetby is a producing UK gas field generating real revenue today, not a hypothetical asset or a story stock ….. The most recent updates confirmed materially higher gas sales in Q4 2025, with revenue north of £4m for the quarter. This came from improved uptime and optimisation, not a one-off spike. Production has stabilised and that directly improves cash generation, which is the only thing that ultimately matters ….. Legacy low-price hedges have now largely rolled off, meaning a much greater proportion of production is being sold at prevailing market prices. Valuing the field as if those old hedges are permanent is simply outdated. Margins today are meaningfully better than they were even six months ago ….. Claims that the company has “no cash” or “no options” also ignore the fact that Angus has been operating for an extended period with limited capex while creditor discussions continue. Lenders are rational actors and benefit far more from supporting a producing asset than forcing failure. That reality is why restructuring talks are ongoing ….. Finally, writing off Saltfleetby as having no future value beyond immediate production shows a lack of perspective. Depleted gas fields with infrastructure and grid access have strategic importance in the UK. Whether people like management or not is irrelevant — the asset has value, and the current market price reflects sentiment, not fundamentals …..

data.author: Sufc100
data.content: As of January 2026, the Saltfleetby Gas Field (wholly owned by Angus Energy) has an estimated going-concern valuation of £55 million to £65 million. This valuation is based on the most recent Competent Persons Report (CPR) and 2025/2026 financial updates. The field is the UK’s largest onshore gas producer and its value is derived from three main areas: 1. Asset Valuation (NPV10) According to the technical audits, the "Net Present Value" (discounted at 10%) of the field’s future cash flows is: P90 (Low Estimate): £57.1 million P50 (Best Estimate): £64.5 million Note: These figures are post-tax and already account for the UK government's Energy Profits Levy (Windfall Tax). 2. Revenue and Production (Going Concern) The field is currently a high-performing "cash cow" for Angus Energy. In the most recent trading update (issued January 22, 2026), the field showed: Quarterly Revenue: £4.12 million (for Q4 2025). Annualized Revenue: Approximately £16 million – £20 million depending on seasonal gas prices. Output: Producing roughly 1.66 million therms of gas per month. 3. Future "Upside" Value Beyond current gas extraction, the field holds significant value for its potential after the gas is gone: Gas Storage: It is considered one of the best candidates in the UK for conversion into a hydrogen storage facility or for Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS). This adds "strategic value" that isn't fully captured in the current £65m gas valuation. New Drilling: Two new wells (SF9 and SF10) were scheduled for 2025 and early 2026 to maintain production "plateau" and accelerate gas extraction. Summary of "Going Concern" Health While the asset itself is valuable, the "going concern" status of the parent company (Angus Energy) was under review in late 2025 due to debt restructuring. However, the January 2026 update indicates a strong recovery, with production surging and legacy low-price "hedges" finally ending, allowing the company to sell gas at full market prices (approx. 102p per therm).

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Bubblepoint, you’re conflating two different things deliberately or otherwise…. RNSs are not meant to read like investor presentations or broker models…. they are regulatory disclosures, and by design they don’t include forward guidance, speculative cash forecasts, or granular commercial negotiations…. That doesn’t make the facts that are disclosed meaningless…. £30m total debt is a fact…. the workover being funded from cash is a fact…. materially higher production post-workover is a fact…. lower opex versus last year is a fact…. and legacy hedges rolling off into a stronger pricing environment is also a fact…. You keep saying “no facts” while ignoring the ones that don’t fit your narrative…. then you fall back on history as if companies are not allowed to change trajectory after restructuring…. that’s analysis anchored in the past, not what’s happening now…. No one here is claiming RNSs tell the entire story…. but they don’t need to…. what matters is direction of travel, and that direction has clearly improved compared with where Angus was heading into default last year…. Cash generation improving, costs down, production up, and debt being restructured at lower rates is not a “wet dream”…. it’s a stabilisation phase…. and stabilisation is exactly what precedes rerating in situations like this…. You’re free to remain sceptical…. but dismissing every positive development as fiction doesn’t make it so…. it just means you’re choosing not to engage with the facts that are already on the table….

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Bubblepoint, you keep reframing every development as a negative regardless of what the RNS actually says…. that might suit a narrative, but it doesn’t reflect what’s being reported…. Calling the recent production uplift a “rabbit out of the hat” ignores the fact that Saltfleetby has always been capable of higher rates once constraints were addressed…. the latest RNS confirms a material improvement following the workover, not some cosmetic bounce…. On the share count point, yes there are a lot of shares in issue…. that’s already well known and fully reflected in the price…. what changes outcomes isn’t the historical capital structure, it’s cash generation and balance sheet repair, and that’s exactly where things are improving…. As for the “new well” scepticism, nobody is pretending it’s risk-free or imminent tomorrow…. the point is that higher current production and stronger margins give Angus options they simply didn’t have before…. optionality matters when a company is coming out of a stressed period…. You also keep anchoring to falling gas prices as if that’s a certainty…. prices fluctuate, but Angus is producing now, into a materially better pricing environment than most of 2024, with legacy hedges rolling off and a much leaner cost base…. that combination is what improves margins, not a single headline price…. No one sensible is saying this is a guaranteed straight line to £7–10m per quarter overnight…. what’s being said is that the trajectory has changed…. higher production, better realised prices, lower costs and active restructuring are all moving in the right direction…. That’s progress…. and it’s exactly what you want to see from a company that’s been in suspension and is working its way back….

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Where discussion often goes off track is treating suspension as evidence of terminal failure rather than a mechanism to protect value while the company sorts out restructuring…. The latest RNS shows production has increased materially post-workover, which directly strengthens the company’s ability to satisfy creditor requirements and move toward resolution of outstanding reporting and governance matters…. Higher production at current gas prices isn’t hypothetical — it’s a current operational fact being reported to the market…. That means stronger cash generation and a far better starting point than the flat-lined or declining production people here keep assuming…. Even if gas prices moderate from current highs, improved production and lower costs still provide significantly more operational cash than before…. That’s exactly the sort of fundamental improvement that de-risks suspension outcomes…. Using worst-case reservoir decline and short “honeymoon” narratives as if they’re the only possible trajectory ignores the actual RNS figures…. No one is saying suspension should be lifted instantly, but the business is making measurable progress toward the thresholds that ultimately do matter in those suspension reviews….

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Bubblepoint, you’re making a lot of assumptions off incomplete information and then presenting the most negative interpretation as if it’s settled fact….. First, the latest RNS didn’t just point to a modest 15–20% uplift — it reported a material increase in production, well ahead of that range. That tells you optimisation is already delivering more than the low expectations you’re anchoring to….. Second, no one has claimed the current intervention is a “permanent fix” in isolation. It’s one step in a wider optimisation programme. Coil tubing, acidisation, flowback management and drawdown control are standard tools to reset well performance and maximise near-term cash generation — which is exactly what Angus needs right now….. The key point you keep overlooking is that Angus no longer requires a perfect reservoir outcome. Higher production today at current gas prices materially improves cash flow, strengthens the balance sheet, and changes the dynamics with creditors. That alone reduces risk versus the situation twelve months ago….. As for gas prices, yes they fluctuate — but the company is producing now into a stronger pricing environment, not modelling distant hypotheticals. Cash in the bank today matters more than speculative decline curves six months out….. Could production moderate over time? Of course. But starting from a significantly higher base, with ongoing optimisation and lower costs, puts Angus in a far better position than the “inevitable failure” scenario you keep repeating….. The latest RNS shows progress, not deterioration. Ignoring that and defaulting to worst-case outcomes doesn’t reflect what’s actually being reported…..

data.author: MoneyRaiser
data.content: Worth grounding this discussion in the latest RNS rather than hypotheticals….. the most recent update confirmed a very material increase in production following the workover, and that’s a real, reported step-change rather than forum speculation….. At this early stage of optimisation, seeing output at these levels is encouraging. No one is claiming this is the final stabilised rate, but starting from a much higher base fundamentally improves the economics. Even a moderation from recent highs still leaves production well ahead of where Angus was operating previously….. Crucially, the company no longer needs heroic assumptions. Higher production at current gas prices translates into strong near-term cash generation, covering opex and materially strengthening the balance sheet. That shifts discussions with creditors and lenders onto far firmer ground than last year….. Yes, reservoir management and decline are always factors, but optimisation is ongoing and the field is delivering today. The narrative that this is all temporary or destined to fail doesn’t align with the actual data being released….. Momentum matters. Rising production, improving cash flow, lower costs, and restructuring discussions backed by operational progress are exactly what the market needs to see. If this trajectory continues, the outlook looks meaningfully better than the constant worst-case scenarios being repeated here…..

data.author: Mirasol
data.content: As BP keeps pointing out  the liquids drop out due the pressure/temperature conditions in the reservoir.  This will continue and can only get worse as you produce more and the reservoir pressure continues to drop. If they have only done a simple acid wash (which appears to be the case) all they've done is to clean up some of the pathways inbetweeen the rock grains near the well bore.  That should lead to a short-term uptick in gas production as gas  will be able to flow more easily to the well.  However it doesn't change the physics.    Fluids will continue to drop out, and if they pull too hard that will eventually totally impede any gas flow.  The well will choke itself to death.  Even a new well will suffer the same problems - unless they can identify a part of the field that has so far been untapped and has near original pressures.  There is zero evidence that this is the case or  that  ANGS have the knowledge or ability to identify such an area should it exist.

data.author: Bubblepoint
data.content: ""Does this intervention not provide a permanent solution to flushing out the liquids?"" The problem with the information this shower of sheite provides, is that it is very limited on detail. BUT from what they HAVE supplied, it pretty much indicates that they are NOT installing velocity strings as part of the workover, it is JUST a simple coil tubing intervention, to pump acid and then to flow out wellbore and near wellbore BANKED liquids and backflow the acid cleanup fluids. Once this has been flushed out, it appears the wells will simply go back on to production as before. WHICH is sheite, because it WILL result in simply inducing MORE liquids and the choking off of free gas continues... So expect an uplift in overall production, of around 15-20% overall, with a short honeymoon period, before a slow continued decline due to those liquids accumulating. Ultimately, it will not bring in the production needed to bail this shower out of the defaulted debt sinkhole they are in, unless gas prices rally and stay at 150p +, which is ALSO unlikely as demand season is quickly coming to an end !!

data.author: HeadInTheSand
data.content: As before, we still don't have the information needed. In terms of senior creditors, ANGS owes Trafigura around £29 million (capital plus annual interest @ 12%). It owes PF around £2 million for the original SFBY purchase. It owes Mercuria and Aleph around £3 million on the eternal 8% ORRI that it's also never paid to date. I honestly forget if there are any other large sums owed - I may well have forgotten remaining amounts to settle previous hedge contracts - but let's go with the £34 million above as a starting point. So... for the last 8+ months, it's been "renegotiating" with Trafigura. We still don't know the terms that Trafigura will impose (and ANGS will have no choice but to accept... or go pop, as per the going concern language in all recent RNSes). Once those are known and there's clearer sight on ANGS's regular opex expenditure and also any future short- to mid-term capex needs, then we'll see what level of post capex/opex monthly revenue ANGS will be required to generate in order to meet the terms of any new refinancing, how possible that is, and what if anything will be left over. Without knowing that stuff, any speculation is pointless.
